But even with that, one big challenge

verified once through Epic need to
repeat that process in every other game

That's frustrating for parents, leads to
unnecessary data collection, and creates
friction for devs, lowering completion
rates in their own flows.
That's what led to the creation of KWS's
age graph, a system designed to make
verification easier for players and
developers alike.
The age graph is KWS's growing network
of nearly 30 million pre-verified
adults. Instead of having parents to
reverify every time their child plays a
new game, the age graph remembers a
parent's verified status alongside their
hashed email address.
The age graph is designed with privacy
at the forefront, storing as little
personal information about the parent as
possible.
This means that the next time a parent
is asked to verify as an adult, they
won't need to reverify again if the game
or service is also powered by KWS.
KWS will simply share the verification
status with the developer requesting
verification and the parent will be
considered verified for the developer's
own VPC purposes.
That means faster onboarding for parents
and kids and higher completion rates for
devs. And as the age graph grows, the
benefits compound. More parents are
pre-verified across more games and
services, and everyone gets smoother and

help navigating the process, KWS handles
it. So you don't have to spin up your
own support function to manage
verification questions worldwide.
This is always one of the questions that
we first get. How will introducing a VPC
flow impact drop off in my experience?
At KWS, we track completion rates
carefully. How many parents who start
the verification process successfully
complete it? And how many underage
minors attempting verification do we
successfully block?
We're continuously improving the
verification flow from UI updates to
onboarding new methods to strengthen
completion rates in markets globally.
And over time, we've seen those those
rates improve significantly, largely
thanks to the power of the age graph.
This year, some partners have seen
between 50 and 70% of all parents skip
the verification flow entirely because
they're already pre-verified in the age
graph. And for those parents, the
process takes about 5 seconds. KWS
checks their status, confirms they're
verified, and that's it.
For parents verifying for the first
time, average completion time depends on
the method that they select, but ranges
generally between 30 and 90 seconds.
That's a huge win for reducing friction
for parents while still keeping kids
safely in the experience.
